Raw Material Extraction.description: Extraction of raw materials such as lithium for batteries, silicon for semiconductors, and metals for phone casing.
Raw Material Extraction.rationale: The extraction of raw materials is a crucial part of device material composition and contributes significantly to environmental impacts.

Intermediate Material Production.description: Production of components like processors, memory chips, and display panels.
Intermediate Material Production.rationale: These components are integral parts of the Galaxy S21 and require significant energy and resources in their production.

Transport to Manufacturer.description: Transporting raw materials and components to Samsung's manufacturing facilities.
Transport to Manufacturer.rationale: Transport contributes to carbon emissions and is a key part of the supply chain.

Assembly and Production.description: The assembly of the Samsung Galaxy S21 in factories, including quality control and packaging.
Assembly and Production.rationale: Assembly is resource-intensive and critically influences the environmental profile of the product.

Distribution.description: Distribution and shipping of the product to various global markets.
Distribution.rationale: Distribution is a significant source of GHG emissions.

N/A.rationale: The installation phase does not apply as the product is a consumer electronic device and does not require professional installation.

Usage.description: The consumer use phase, including mobile network connectivity and screen usage.
Usage.rationale: Consumer usage is critical for understanding energy consumption during the lifetime of the product.

Software Updates.description: Regular software updates improve functionality but consume resources during their development and deployment.
Software Updates.rationale: Maintaining software is necessary for security and performance, impacting energy use.

Repairs.description: Repair processes including screen replacement and battery changes.
Repairs.rationale: Repairs extend the product lifespan and can reduce the environmental impacts compared to full replacement.

Replacement with New Models.description: Lifecycle impacts of consumers replacing their devices with newer models.
Replacement with New Models.rationale: Replacement affects lifecycle impact assessments as older models may be discarded or recycled.

N/A.rationale: Refurbishment is typically not performed by end-users for this type of product.

Electricity Usage.description: Electricity consumed during usage, for charging and network communication.
Electricity Usage.rationale: Significant energy consumption occurs during device charging over its lifespan.

N/A.rationale: Water is not typically used during the operation or use phase of this electronic device.
Deinstallation is not applicable to consumer electronics like mobile phones, which are not installed in a typical sense.

Transport to Recycling Facility.description: Transport of obsolete devices to recycling facilities.
Transport to Recycling Facility.rationale: This stage is essential for managing electronic waste responsibly.

Recycling Processes.description: Breaking down the phones into components and recycling valuable materials.
Recycling Processes.rationale: Ensures materials are reclaimed and reduces the need for virgin materials.

E-waste Disposal.description: Disposal of non-recyclable materials in appropriate waste facilities.
E-waste Disposal.rationale: Proper disposal reduces environmental harm and is the final lifecycle stage.
